title: Minute's silence to mark loss of Rotherham men who died in Didcot collapse while families 'still battle for answers' | Calendar
text:
The families of those killed in the Didcot Power Station collapse are "still battling for answers" a year on.
Ken Cresswell and John Shaw, both from Rotherham, were among four men to lose their lives after the partial collapse of the boiler house at the Didcot A plant a year ago today.
A minute's silence will be observed at the site today to mark the memories of the men and talks are ongoing about the building of a permanent memorial to them.
But lawyers at Irwin Mitchell, who represent the families of Mr Cresswell, Mr Shaw and Mr Huxtable, have said "uncertainty" is causing distress to the victims' relatives.
The Didcot site following the collapse. Credit: PA The tragic disaster that occurred at the Didcot Power Station last February will live long in the memories of those who witnessed it and those who lost family and friends.
The lives of the families we represent have been changed forever and the uncertainty about the current situation continues to cause them an unbelievable amount of distress, particularly after the ordeal they went through before their loved ones were finally recovered.
The families want to know why this terrible event occurred and we will support them in getting the answers they deserve.
As the anniversary passes it is a timely reminder that it has been a year since the accident and the families are still battling for answers.
